data.text:
All gates before you go
through the narrow,
through the narrowest,
because it is uncertain to know where enemies
sit on the surface.

Give health!
A guest has come in,
where shall he sit? Very soon
he who is on the edge shall try his luck too.

Fire is needed by those who have come in
and on their knees the coal.
Food and shelter are needed by a man,
by those who have gone over the mountain.

Water is needed by those who come to
the end, dry and popular,
good for the thirst if they can find
words and silence.

In his thinking a man should be brave,
keeps his mind on guard; then he comes to the palace of the world,
and seldom is wise in speech,
because a man never finds a friend more unshakable
than great human wisdom.

In the house of a guest, who comes to the house,
he listens to a thin sound,
listens with his ears,
but sees with his eyes;
so each learns new things before him.

Happy is he who gets too much
praise and praise for himself;

it is worse with that,
that a man should have another's breasts in him.

Happy is he who himself is too much
praise and knowledge,
while he lives;
because a man has often taken evil counsel from another's breasts.
A better burden is a man's burden than a man's wisdom; a better fortune is a man's burden in an unknown place; such is the fate of the wicked.
A better burden is a man's burden than a man's wisdom; a worse reward is a man's reward than a man's excessive drinking of ale.
It is as good as good to say good to the sons of the ages, for to bear is known, the more one drinks to one's heart's content.
The unforgetable is he who thunders above the ages, he steals the heart's content; with the feathers of that bird I bound a raven in Gunnlad's garden.
I became an ale, I became a prey to the wise Fjalar; therefore the ages are best, that each one will later claim his own heart's content.

The nation's children should be quiet and thoughtful
and brave in battle; each one should be cheerful and cheerful
until his time awaits death.

An unwise man thinks you will live,
if he avoids slaughter;
but evil gives him no peace,
even if the gypsies give him.

A blind man who comes to meet,
shall hide or roar;
everything is sudden, if he can get too much,
then the mood of the gypsy is high.

He alone knows who has wandered far
and has traveled many times,
what mood guides each gypsy,
he who knows is wise.

If a man holds a vessel,
drinks mead in moderation,
speaks or keeps silent,
no one will know that you go to bed early.

A greedy man, unless he knows his mind,
seems to be old;
often gets a laugh, who comes with a wickedness,
to a man with a foolish stomach.

Herds know when they are to go home,
and then go off to pasture;
but an ill-tempered man can always
know his stomach's language.

A wretched man and a bad temper
laughs at everything;
but he knows, when he should know,
that he is a bad-tempered man.

An ill-tempered man stays awake all night
and thinks about everything;
Then the mother, who comes in the morning,
all is as it was.

A foolish man thinks he knows everything,
if he has a bad life;
but he knows
what to say,
if his temptation comes.

A wise man is he who can tell a story
and say the same;
sons of knowledge may hide a secret,
that is what goes around.

He who is always silent speaks with dignity,
with a pointless speech;
a hasty tongue, unless it is restrained,
often sees itself as too good.

In an instant a man shall have another,
though he comes to know;
many then a wise man thinks,
if he is known-at
and he reaches the dry mountain thunder.

A wise man thinks, he who takes flight,
goes to the top of the hill;
a wise man is he who is too worthy to smile,
though he with a grudge roars.

Many old men are good-natured,
but their value is evil;
the gossip of ages will always be,
a guest with a guest.

A man must often get a few every year,
unless he comes to meet:
a scoundrel and a swindler, pretending to be sold
and can report that he has got a few.

A bad friend is a great enemy,
even though he is on a farm,
but to a good friend
there are paths open,
even though he is far away.

A guest must walk,
and be an island in one place;
a sweet thing becomes sad, if he sits long
elsewhere.

A farm is better,
though it is small,
but each has a home;
though two goats are not and a hall is torn,
it is still better than a prayer.

A farm is better, though it be small,
everyone is at home;
a bloody heart, those who ask should
take care of every matter.

A man shall advance with his weapon on foot,
because it is uncertain to know,
when the need of the poor will arise on the roads of the wilderness.

I have found a gentle man or such good food,
that it would be accepted silently,
or his cattle
so clever [clever], that if he endures, his suffering is a reward.

Know that if you have a friend, one whom you trust well,
and you want to get good from him,
you should mix good with him
and exchange gifts, and go and find him often.

If you have another, one whom you trust badly,
and you want to get good from him,
you should speak nicely to him,
but think lightly
and repay slander with lies.

It is still more for one whom you trust badly
and you suspect of his disposition,
you should laugh with him and speak from the heart;
similarly, rewards should be given with gifts.

I was young once, I went alone,
then I became lost;
I thought that wealth, when I found another,
a man is a man's delight.

Gentle, bold men live best,
seldom do they grow;
but an unwise man, fearing the heat,
is always quick to give gifts.

The hill on which a village stands,
is warmed by neither bark nor needles;
such is a man, who is a man's friend.
How long shall he live?

A hotter fire burns
with bad friends, peace five days,
but then it goes out, when the wind comes in,
and all friendship deteriorates.

One great thing shall be given to a man;
often buys himself in little praise,
with half a loaf and with a poor vessel
I gained a companion.

The average man's snore is every man,
life to snore is;
no one knows his fate,
for he is the most carefree of sorrows.

Fire burns from fire, until the fire is,
a fire is kindled by a fire;
A man of man becomes a sheep in speech,
but a swindler in secret.

A year shall rise, he who otherwise wants
to have money or life;
seldom does a lying wolf
learn too much, nor a sleeping man win.

A year shall rise, he who is on labor,
and goes to his work with understanding;
much too long, he who sleeps in the morning,
is half empty under the waters.

Dry skis and roofed with snow,
that a man knows well, of that wood,
that may win matters and seasons.

Washed and fed
a man rides to the Thing,
though he is well-prepared;
No man can wear and wear a horse's coat, even if he has a good one.

A hawk and a hawk come to the sea,
an eagle to the age;
so is a man who comes with many,
and to the few he speaks.

He who is wise shall tell and tell,
he who wants to be called a hawk;
one shall know neither another,
a nation knows, if three row.

-- -- -- --
-- -- -- --
the words of those who say to others
often he gets too much.

I came very early to many places,
but late to some;
Beer was drunk, some were bad,
rarely does sorrow meet in the land.

Here and elsewhere would I be invited home too,
if I needed a meal,
or two leathers hung at the feet of a faithful friend,
where I had eaten one.

Fire is best with strong sons
and the sun's sight, his health,
if a man has reached,
without the vice of living.

Is-that a man is all wretched,
even though he is ill-healthy;
some are happy because of their sons, some because of their relatives,
some because of their wealth, some because of their deeds.

It is better to live than not to live,
you cannot get a live cow;
I saw a fire burning a rich man,
but outside was dead before the door.

A lame horse rides, a herd is driven by an untrained hand,
a dull road and a good one,
a blind man is better than a burnt one,
a useful man's hand.

A son is better, though he is too late to be raised
after a long journey;
seldom do stones stand near the path,
unless they rise up and fall.

Two horses are like armies, the tongue is the death of the head;
is to me in the heat of each hand a pleasure.

He who knows, who knows not,
many are made of gold;
one is rich, another is poor,
let him bear the burden of the great danger.

Money dies, relatives die,
self dies the same,
but reputation never dies,
whoever gets good for himself.

Money dies, relatives die,
self dies the same,
I know one thing that never dies:
a judgment on each death.

Full gates I saw for Fitjung's sons,
now they bear the choice of dangers;
so is wealth as the twinkling of an eye,
he is the choicest of friends.

A worthless man,
if he gains
money or valuables,
he is ambitious,
but never human wisdom,
he goes far in secret.

That is then proven, if you ask the runes
of the wise men,
who made the sly
and got the fimbulthul, then he has bettered if he keeps silent.

At evening the day shall be permitted,
a woman who is burned, a mache who is tried,
a maiden who is given, ice that comes over,
a beer that is drunk.

In the wind we shall chop wood,
weather at sea calm, darkness with man can talk,
many are the eyes of the day; on a ship shall creep strength,
but on a shield for protection, a mache for a blow,
but a maiden for a kiss.

By fire we shall drink ale,
but on ice we shall crawl, a lean man buys,
but a dirty man buys, a horse at home is fat,
but a dog on a farm.

A maiden's words should not be believed by man
nor what a woman says, because at what

Even if one meets his brother's death on the road,
a house half-burnt, a horse all broken,
- then the sea is useless if one leg is broken -,
a man becomes so sure that he believes all this.

Such is the peace of women, those who think lightly,
who drive unbridled on slippery ice,
tough, two-year-old and is poorly tamed,
or in a stormy wind graze uncontrollably,
or must throw the lame clean in the mountains.

Now I speak plainly, for I know both,
that men's hearts are kind to women;
then we speak most beautifully, when we are full of thoughts:
that seduces a cruel heart.

He who wants to get the love of a poet,
like the pleasure of a bright man,
he who gets it is free.

"Even nearer the evening, Odin, you must come,
if you wish to speak to me;
all things are unrighteous, unless some know
such a fate together."

Then I departed and we thought
wisely we would leave;
but I thought that I had formed
her mind and joy.

So I came next, that in the new year the whole village was
already awake with burning lights
and burnt wood, so was the path too familiar to me.

Even nearer the morning, when I had still come,
then Saldrót was too asleep;
poor one I then found the good woman
tied to pray.

In the old giant I sought,
now I have come again too: little I could silently there;
many words I spoke in my fame
in Suttung's halls.

Gunnlöð gave me a golden chair to
drink the expensive mead;
ill fees I left her to have
for her whole mind, for her severe rest.

Rata's mouth let us
have too few rooms and gnaw on stones;
Over and under the giants' paths,
so I venture to head.

I have used well-bought color well,
few are wanting to the wise,
because Oðrerir
has now risen in the age of the edge.

In the dead of day the frost-thirs
went to Háva's council to tell Háva's hall;
that they asked Bölverk,
if he had come with bonds
or had Suttungr too seen him.

Oðinn the ogre, I think, has succeeded;
what shall his loyal ones believe?
Suttung the betrayer he let slip
and weep Gunnlöða.

We advise you, Loddfáfnir,
but you take advice, -
you should enjoy, if you take, you will be good,
if you can -:
never stretch out your ear to another woman's wife.

We advise you, Loddfáfnir,
but you take advice, -
you should enjoy, if you take, you will be good, if you can -:
on a mountain or a fjord, if times go well for you,
you will find that you are worth well.

We advise you, Loddfáfnir,
but you will learn advice, -
you will enjoy it if you learn, you will be good if you can -:
never let a bad man know of misfortune,
because from an evil man you will never get
the rewards of a good heart.

I saw a wicked woman bite the tail
of a wicked woman;
her tongue became a slanderer
and she bore too much of a true sin.

We advise you, Loddfáfnir,
but you will learn advice, -
you will enjoy it if you learn, you will be good if you can -:
know that if you have a friend,
the one you trust well,
you will often go to find,
because the grass grows
and the path is long, which the wind treads.

We advise you, Loddfáfnir,
but you will learn advice, -
you will enjoy it, if you learn,
you will be good, if you can -:
reach out to a good man for the runes of fun
and learn the magic of healing, while you live.

We advise you, Loddfáfnir,
but you will learn advice, -
you will enjoy it, if you learn,
you will be good, if you can -:
never be your friend before the tides of war;
sorrow is the heart, if you speak nor reach
someone's whole mind.

We advise you, Loddfáfnir, but you who take advice, -
you will enjoy it, if you take it,
you will do good, if you can -:
you shall never exchange words
with a useless monkey,

For from an evil man you will never
get good wages,
but a good man
will make you able to praise.

We advise you, Loddfáfnir, but you who take advice, -
you will enjoy it, if you take it, if you can -:
with three words at a time you shall often get better roads with a worse man,
then there is a worse road.

We advise you, Loddfáfnir,
but you who learn advice, -
you will enjoy it, if you learn,
you will do good, if you can -:
you will not be a shoemaker or a shoemaker,
unless you yourself see:
a shoe is made badly or a shoe is wrong,
then you will ask for evil.

We advise you, Loddfáfnir,
but you who learn advice, -
you will enjoy it, if you learn,
you will do good, if you can -:
where you know evil, curse yourself,
and give peace to your enemies.

We advise you, Loddfáfnir,
but you who learn advice, -
you will enjoy it, if you learn,
you will do good, if you can -:
never rejoice in evil,
but let yourself be blessed.

We advise you, Loddfáfnir, but you who learn advice, -
you will enjoy it, if you learn,
you will be good, if you can -:
you shall look up in battle,
- the sons of the brave will become like the sons of the brave, -
then yours will be of good tails.

We advise you, Loddfáfnir, but you who learn advice, -
you will enjoy it, if you can -:
if you want to greet a good woman at the Gamanrunum
and get joy from her, you should call her beautiful
and let her be firm;
you will be a good person, if you can.

We advise you, Loddfáfnir, but you who learn advice, -
you will enjoy it, if you learn,
you will be good, if you can -:
I ask you to be careful and not over-careful;
Be careful with beer and with another woman
and with the third thing, that thieves and games.

We advise you, Loddfáfnir, but you will learn the advice, -
you will enjoy it, if you learn,
you will be good, if you can -:
that you will never laugh at a guest or a passerby.

Often the wicked know, those who sit inside,
what kind of people they are, who come;
is-that a man is so good at fault that he does not follow,
nor so bad that even one is enough.

We advise you, Loddfáfnir, but you will learn the advice, -
you will enjoy it, if you learn,
you will be good, if you can -:
that you will never laugh at hair,
oft is good,
that which the old men say;
Often from a sharp bellows come words understood
to those who hang with height and strike with arrows
and wave with willpower.

We advise you, Loddfáfnir, but you learn advice, -
you will enjoy, if you learn,
you will be good, if you can -:
you will neither go astray nor on a fence;
you can choose well.

That tree is framed, which shall ride
to all to the end;
give a bow, or it will ask
you to lock each one on the line.

We advise you, Loddfáfnir, but you will learn advice, -
you will enjoy it if you learn, you will be good if you can -:
where you drink ale, choose from the earth,
because earth takes on age, but fire with the sick,
oak with the sick, axe with the many-knowledged,
hall with the hirgo, -
the moon shall greet the fierce, -
graze with the bitten, but with the curse of the runes,
fold with the flood shall take.

I know that I will hew the windy wound on
all nine nights, a thorn unfurled
and given to Odin,
myself myself,
on that wound that no man knows
from whose roots flows.

Then I learned to be wise and to be wise
and to grow and to have good conduct,
word sought for word
of word
of word, deed sought for deed
of deed
of deed.

Runes you will find and make staves,
very large staves, very stiff staves,
which the fiddle-stud got and
made the gin-regin
and raised the ravens.

Odin with the Óðas, but for the elves Dáinn,
Dvalinn and for the dwarves,
Ásvíðr for the giants,
I raised summer myself.

Do you know what to ask for? Do you know what to decide?
Do you know what to get? Do you know what to tempt?
Do you know what to pray for? Do you know what to sacrifice?
Do you know what to send? Do you know what to sow?

Better is not asked than too much sacrificed,
or a gift of value;
better is not sent than too much sown.
So did Thunder rise for the people's cause,
when he rose up and came back.

I know those poems,
which the women of the people and the weak of man can know.
Help is one thing, but that will help you
with sins and sorrows and bitter pits.

I know another,
which sons must push,
those who want to live with doctors.

I know the third thing:
If I have great need of restraint from my wrath,
If I quell my anger,
No weapon will bite them.

I know the fourth thing:
If I have chains on my limbs,
So I can walk,
The fetters will spring from my feet, but the chains will be taken from my hands.

I know the fifth thing:
If I am shot by a few arrows in a crowd of people,
He is so strong that I can stand still, if I see him too.

I know this sixth:
If a man wounds me with the mouth of a raw wood,
And that tail that my anger calls,
That my soul rather eats than me.

I know this seventh:
If I see a hall of places burning high,
Burning so wide that I can save him;
That I can spell to cry.

I know this eighth, which is useful for all to understand:
Where hatred grows among the sons of the noble,
That I can soon fix.

I know this ninth:
If I am too weak to save
My ship on the water,
I will sail on a calm wind and sleep the whole sea.

I know the tenth:
If I see a field horse playing in the air,
I so work that they wander
to their homes, to their homesickness.

I know the eleventh:
If I am to lead a long-lost friend to battle,
and I will lead them in stripes,
but they go with their kingdom
safely, safely away,
and come safe from where.

I know the twelfth:
If I see a tree
up high in the air,
then I rise and in the runes I find,
that it walks gracefully and speaks to me.

I know the thirteenth:
If I am to throw water on a young citizen,
he will fall, even though he comes among the people,
he will fall before the horses.

That I know the fourteenth:
If I should count the first ten for the first time,
Aesir and Elf I know all the difference;
Few know the unsung so.

That I know the fifteenth
is the cry of Þjóðrerir the dwarf for Delling's door:
He cried mightily to the Aesir, but before the Elfs,
the thought of Hroftatý.

That I know the sixteenth:
If I want to have all the spirit and fun of a swinish man, I will turn my mind
to a white-armed woman, and I will turn to her for all her comfort.

That I know the seventeenth
that I will soon be alienated
from the young man.
You, Loddfáfnir,
will long be accustomed to this poem;
though it is good for you if you can,
useful if you learn, necessary if you accept.

Now the Hava words are recited in the Hava hall,
all the need of the sons of the giants, no need of the sons of the giants;
blessed is he who recited, blessed is he who knows,
enjoys he who has learned, blessed are those who obeyed.
